children.subject: This is just my 2 cents, but I'd argue that it's "easier" to have someone with great research experience to take a couple of undergraduate classes during their program than it is to have someone who's taken classes with little hands-on experience to do good research. So, I don't think lacking a couple of classes would contribute significantly to someone getting rejected (of courses, there are other factors, so admission can't be guaranteed with just these 2 pieces of info.).

Also, EE126 and EE127 are basically more of Math classes than EE. The ideal classes for intro to EE would be EE16AB + EE120.

Being an Applied Math major, if your probability is strong and you've taken Math 170, then you pretty much covered the topics in 126/127 already.

history.content:
There is much talk on this forum about classes like EE126 and EE127. Prof. Sahai in particular has repeatedly emphasized that these classes are extremely important for people who aim to do graduate school in an area of EECS relating to AI/ML/control.

I am not an EECS/CS major, instead I am Applied Math - 3 CS classes (170,188, currently in 189) form my cluster. I have never taken a single class from the EE department here and I am graduating (so will not be able to). I also aim to apply to some EE PHD programs. However I do have significant research experience with faculty in EECS in this area.

My question is as follows: are there ever cases when someone who has strong research is rejected simply because they didn't take a particular class from that department? i.e. if someone comes from a background other than EECS (and hence lacks traditional classes like 127) but demonstrates capacity to do research in the area, is this different background considered a dealbreaker?

A response from an instructor would be much appreciated, thank you!!
history.subject: how important are particular classes for grad school apps?
